G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 31.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in the Bristol County Probate and Family Court pursuant to G.L. c. 215, § 3 and G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31, because the prior custody and parenting‑time judgment was entered in this Court and the child resides within the Commonwealth.

General Laws c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: General Laws c. 208, § 28 authorizes the Court to “make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment” regarding custody and parenting time upon a showing of changed circumstances and the child’s best interests.

General Laws c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: General Laws c. 208, § 31 provides that custody and visitation orders shall be made “in accordance with the best interests of the child,” and that the Court may grant sole or shared legal and/or physical custody and may impose conditions on parenting time as needed.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7\u00a7 3 and 6.proposition: The Probate and Family Court’s equitable jurisdiction, including under G.L. c. 215, §§ 3 and 6, empowers it to fashion appropriate, child‑centered remedies and safeguards, including supervised parenting time, substance‑use–related conditions, and other protective measures.

General Laws c. 209C, \u00a7 10.proposition: General Laws c. 209C, § 10 (though primarily governing children born out of wedlock) similarly reflects the Legislature’s intent that custody and visitation be subject to modification when required by the child’s best interests, reinforcing the general principle applicable here.

Although the case ultimately vacates the custody modification for lack of adequate findings on best interests, it clearly affirms the legal rule described in the proposition, and thus is properly cited as authority for that standard.

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: In determining the best interests of the child, the Court considers, among other factors, the child’s physical safety, emotional security, and the parties’ relative abilities to provide a stable, nurturing, and sober environment. Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the best-interests-of-the-child standard generally and emphasizes stability, continuity of caregiving, and the child’s welfare, but it does not specifically articulate a factor test framed in terms of the child’s physical safety, emotional security, or a ‘sober’ environment. The court’s analysis focuses on primary caregiving, work schedules, day care, and attentiveness to medical, educational, and daily needs, rather than explicitly on sobriety or emotional security as distinct factors. Thus, while broadly consistent with a welfare-focused best-interests inquiry, the case does not clearly establish the specific multi-factor proposition as quoted.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “However, we will not sustain an award of custody ‘unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed.’ … The required considerations of the second paragraph of G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), neither replace the ‘best interests of the child’ standard nor limit the factors that a judge may consider in determining what custodial arrangements are in the best interests of the child. … Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child.”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: These developments directly implicate Ethan’s safety, his need for adequate sleep and routine, and his emotional sense of security, and therefore go to the heart of the best‑interests analysis mandated by G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 & 31, and cases such as Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, and Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The proposition claims Vaughn as authority that developments affecting a child’s safety, sleep, routine, and emotional security go to the core of the best‑interests analysis under G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 & 31. Custody of Vaughn does emphasize that domestic violence and its effects on a child are fundamental best‑interests considerations and requires explicit findings under § 31 when there is a 209A order, but it does not discuss sleep, routine, or day‑to‑day stability in the manner suggested. The case supports the broader point that safety and emotional security are central to best‑interests analysis, but not the more specific aspects of sleep and routine, so the citation is somewhat over‑reading the opinion.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: “We endorse the Appeals Court’s commitment to the propositions that physical force within the family is both intolerable and too readily tolerated, and that a child who has been either the victim or the spectator of such abuse suffers a distinctly grievous kind of harm.… Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.”
